It can, therefore, be used to prove that a function has a limit at a point, but it can never be used to prove that a function does not have a limit at a point.<ref>{{cite book
cannot be found by taking any number of limits along paths that pass through the point, but since

* [http://demonstrations.wolfram.com/SqueezeTheorem/ Squeeze Theorem] by Bruce Atwood (Beloit College) after work by, Selwyn Hollis (Armstrong Atlantic State University), the [[Wolfram Demonstrations Project]].

column2: caption        = Lincoln wearing a military-style uniform, c. 1864
relatives      = See [[Lincoln family tree]] or [[Edward Baker Lincoln]] (brother), [[Robert Todd Lincoln]] (brother), [[William Wallace Lincoln]] (brother)

column1: '''Thomas \"Tad\" Lincoln III''' (April 4, 1853 – July 15, 1871) was the fourth and youngest son of [[Abraham Lincoln
column2: Abraham]] and [[Mary Todd Lincoln]]. The nickname \"Tad\" was given to him by his father, who observed that he had a large head and was \"as wiggly as a tadpole\" when he was a baby. Lincoln was known to be impulsive and unrestrained, and he did not attend school during his father's lifetime. He had free run of the [[White House]], and there are stories of him interrupting presidential meetings, collecting animals, and charging visitors to see his father. He died at the age of 18 on July 15, 1871, in [[Chicago]].

column1: Lincoln was born on April 4, 1853,<ref>Manning (2016), page 75</ref> the fourth son of [[Abraham Lincoln]] and [[Mary Todd Lincoln
column2: Mary Todd]]. His three elder brothers were [[Robert Todd Lincoln
column6: date=February 2018}} Named after his paternal grandfather [[Thomas Lincoln]] and uncle Thomas Lincoln, Jr., the fourth boy was soon nicknamed \"Tad\" by his father, for his small body and large head, and because he wiggled like a [[tadpole]] as an infant.<ref name=\"wead8990\">Wead (2003), pp. 89–90.</ref><ref>{{Cite book
column8: title=Father Lincoln: The Untold Story of Abraham Lincoln and His Boys--Robert, Eddy, Willie, and Tad
column14: language=en}}</ref> Lincoln's first name has occasionally been erroneously recorded as Thaddeus.<ref>Bayne (2001), p. 13</ref>

column1: Lincoln was born with a form of [[cleft lip and palate]], causing him speech problems throughout his life. He had a [[lisp]] and delivered his words rapidly and unintelligibly.<ref name=\"hutchinson2\">Hutchinson (2009), para. 2.</ref> Often only those close to Lincoln were able to understand him.<ref name=\"hutchinson11\">Hutchinson (2009), para. 11.</ref><ref name=\"Bayne3\">Bayne (2001), p. 3.</ref> For example, he called his father's bodyguard, [[William H. Crook]], \"Took\", and his father \"Papa Day\" instead of \"Papa Dear\".<ref name=\"hutchinson16\">Hutchinson (2009), para. 16.</ref> The cleft palate contributed to uneven teeth; he had such difficulty chewing food that his meals were specially prepared.<ref name=\"hutchinson22\">Hutchinson (2009), para. 22.</ref>
Lincoln and his brother Willie were considered \"notorious hellions\" during the period they lived in Springfield. They were recorded by their father's law partner [[William Herndon (lawyer)
column2: William Herndon]] as having turned their law office upside down, pulling the books off the shelves, while their father appeared oblivious to their behavior.<ref name=\"wead90\">Wead (2003), p. 90.</ref>

column3: Tad Lincoln with his father looking at a photo album]]

column1: Upon their father's election as President, both Tad and Willie moved into the White House and it became their new playground and home. At the request of Mrs. Lincoln, [[Julia Taft Bayne
column2: Julia Taft]] brought her younger brothers, 14-year-old \"Bud\" (Horatio Nelson Taft Jr., 1847–1915) and 12-year-old \"Holly\" (Halsey Cook Taft, 1849–1897), to the White House, and they became playmates of the two young Lincolns.<ref name=\"wead91\">Wead (2003), p. 91.</ref><ref name=\"Bayne1-3\">Bayne (2001), pp. 1–3.</ref>

column1: In February 1862, both Lincoln boys contracted [[typhoid fever]] and both boys were bedridden. Willie died on February 20, while Tad recovered. However he cried for a month, not only for his brother's death, but for the loss of his other two playmates Bud and Holly, for his mother sent them away after Willie's death, because they reminded her too much of him. After Willie's death, Tad's parents became even more lenient toward Tad's behavior, and Tad spent nearly all his time with his father.<ref name=\"wead9192\">Wead (2003), pp. 91–92.</ref>

During the time his father was alive, Tad was impulsive, unrestrained, and did not attend school. [[John Hay]] wrote that the boy's numerous tutors in the White House usually quit in frustration. Tad had free run of the White House, and there are stories of him interrupting presidential meetings, collecting animals, charging visitors to see his father, and more.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=R. J. Brown. Tad Lincoln: The Not-so-Famous Son of A Most-Famous President

column1: On April 14, 1865, Tad went to [[National Theatre (Washington, D.C.)
column2: Grover's Theatre]] to see the play ''Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp'' while his parents attended the performance of ''[[Our American Cousin]]'' at [[Ford's Theatre]]. That night, his father was [[Assassination of Abraham Lincoln
column3: fatally shot]] by [[John Wilkes Booth]]. When news of the assassination spread to Grover's Theatre, the manager made an announcement to the entire audience. Tad began running and screaming, \"They killed Papa! They killed Papa!\" He was escorted back to the White House while his mother pleaded to have him brought to his father's deathbed at the [[Petersen House]]. \"Bring Tad—he will speak to Tad—he loves him so.\" Late that night, an inconsolable Tad was put to bed by a White House doorman.<ref name=\"wead93\">Wead (2003), p. 93.</ref> President Lincoln died the next morning, on Saturday, April 15, at 7:22 am.<ref name = \"Heritage\">{{cite journal
column10: author=Richard A. R. Fraser, MD}}</ref> About the death of his father, Tad said:

column1: Pa is dead. I can hardly believe that I shall never see him again. I must learn to take care of myself now. Yes, Pa is dead, and I am only Tad Lincoln now, little Tad, like other little boys. I am not a president's son now. I won't have many presents anymore. Well, I will try and be a good boy, and will hope to go someday to Pa and brother Willie, in Heaven.<ref name=\"wead9394\">Wead (2003), pp. 93–94.</ref>

After the assassination, Mary, Robert, and Tad Lincoln lived together in Chicago.  Robert moved out after a short time, and Tad began attending school. In 1868, they left Chicago and lived in Europe for almost three years, in Germany and later in England.<ref name=\"Emerson\">{{cite book
column4: title=Giant in the Shadows: The Life of Robert T. Lincoln

column1: Lincoln suffered from what one modern commentator has called a \"complex speech and language disorder\" related to some form of a cleft lip or palate. This caused some problems when Lincoln was in school in Chicago.  While at the [[Elizabeth Street School (Chicago)
column2: Elizabeth Street School]], his schoolmates sometimes called him \"Stuttering Tad\" because of the speech impediment,<ref>{{cite journal
column5: title=What Was Tad Lincoln's Speech Problem?
column6: journal=Journal of the Abraham Lincoln Association
column11: accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> which he was able to overcome as a teenager.<ref name = \"Emerson\"/>

column1: On Saturday morning, July 15, 1871, Lincoln died at the age of 18.<ref name=\"Classroom\">{{cite web
column2: title=Abraham Lincoln and Chicago (Abraham Lincoln's Classroom)
column5: accessdate=December 2, 2012}}</ref> The cause of death has been variously referred to as [[tuberculosis]],<ref>{{cite book
column8: title=In Lincoln's Footsteps: A Historical Guide to the Lincoln Sites in Illinois
column13: pleuristic]] attack,<ref>Emerson, Jason. Giant in the Shadows: The Life of Robert T. Lincoln. Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press, 2012, P. 478.</ref> [[pneumonia]],<ref name=\"Classroom\"/> or [[congestive heart failure]].<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Giant in the Shadows:The Life of Robert T. Lincoln
column25: quote=With serious effusion compressing the lungs and crowding the nearby heart, there was not enough oxygen to maintain the life centers of the brain}} (quoting Milton Shutes, \"Mortality of the Five Lincoln Boys\", ''Lincoln Herald'', vol. 57 (Spring 1955), p. 7.)</ref> Lincoln's death occurred at the Clifton House hotel in Chicago.<ref>Davenport, Page 153</ref> In an obituary, [[John Hay]] affectionately referred to him as \"Little Tad\".<ref>{{cite book
column28: title=At Lincoln's Side: John Hay's Civil War Correspondence and Selected Writings

column1: Funeral services were held for Lincoln in his brother Robert's home in Chicago. His body was transported to Springfield and buried in the [[Lincoln Tomb]] at [[Oak Ridge Cemetery]], alongside his father and two of his brothers. Robert accompanied the casket on the train, but Mary was too distraught to make the trip.<ref>Davenport, pages 153 –154</ref>
On film and television Tad Lincoln has been portrayed by,
* Newton Hall in ''[[The Dramatic Life of Abraham Lincoln]]'' (1924)

column2: Dickie Moore]] in ''[[Lincoln in the White House]]'' (1939, Short)

column1: * Henry Blair in ''[[Abe Lincoln in Illinois (film)
* [[Robby Benson]] in ''[[The Last of Mrs. Lincoln]]'' (1976)
* [[Adam Lamberg]] in ''[[The Day Lincoln Was Shot]]'' (1998)

column5: title=What Was Tad Lincoln's Speech Problem?
column6: journal=Journal of the Abraham Lincoln Association

column3: Brazilian]] club [[Associação Social e Esportiva Sada

column1: Marcelo Méndez began his career as a coach in 1986.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=El argentino Marcelo Méndez, nuevo seleccionador español
column7: accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> In 2003 he became an assistant coach of the Spanish club [[CV Pòrtol]] and a head coach of the same club in 2005. During his four-year work at the club, his team won three [[Superliga de Voleibol Masculina
column8: Spanish Championships]], one [[Copa del Rey de Voleibol
column9: Spanish Cup]] and three [[Supercopa de España de Voleibol
column10: Supercups]]. In 2007 he replaced [[Andrea Anastasi]] as a head coach of the [[Spain men's national volleyball team]]. In 2009 he became a head coach of [[Associação Social e Esportiva Sada
column11: Sada Cruzeiro]]. While being a coach of Sada Cruzeiro for over 10 years he won '''three''' [[FIVB Volleyball Men's Club World Championship
column12: Club World Champion]] titles, '''seven''' [[Men's South American Volleyball Club Championship
column13: South American Club Champion]] titles and '''six''' [[Brazilian Men's Volleyball Superliga
column14: Brazilian Champion]] titles what makes him one of the world`s most successful volleyball coaches.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Argentinean coach Méndez changed volleyball landscape in Sada Cruzeiro
column21: title=Marcelo Mendez completa uma década de títulos pelo Sada Cruzeiro
column25: accessdate=3 April 2020}}</ref> In both 2016 and 2017 he was one of the candidates to take over [[Poland men's national volleyball team]].<ref>{{cite web
column27: title=POL M: Polish Volleyball Federation made shortlist - 3 Italians, 1 Serb and main favorite Marcelo Mendez!
column32: title=Marcelo Méndez cerca de convertirse en entrenador de la Selección de Polonia
column38: title=Marcelo Mendez continua no Sada Cruzeiro: Polônia anuncia técnico
column42: accessdate=3 April 2020}}</ref> In 2018 he became a head coach of the [[Argentina men's national volleyball team]] signing a six-year contract.<ref>{{cite web

column1: In 2003 Marcelo Méndez became an assistant coach of the Spanish club [[CV Pòrtol]] and a head coach of the same club in 2005. During his four-year work at the club, his team won three [[Superliga de Voleibol Masculina
column2: Spanish Championships]], one [[Copa del Rey de Voleibol
column3: Spanish Cup]] and three [[Supercopa de España de Voleibol
column4: Supercups]]. In 2007 he replaced [[Andrea Anastasi]] as a head coach of the [[Spain men's national volleyball team]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=El argentino Marcelo Méndez, nuevo seleccionador español
column10: accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref> In 2009 he became a head coach of [[Associação Social e Esportiva Sada
column11: Sada Cruzeiro]]. While being a coach of Sada Cruzeiro for over 10 years he won '''three''' [[FIVB Volleyball Men's Club World Championship
column12: Club World Champion]] titles, '''seven''' [[Men's South American Volleyball Club Championship
column13: South American Club Champion]] titles and '''six''' [[Brazilian Men's Volleyball Superliga
column14: Brazilian Champion]] titles what makes him one of the world`s most successful volleyball coaches.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Argentinean coach Méndez changed volleyball landscape in Sada Cruzeiro
column21: title=Marcelo Mendez completa uma década de títulos pelo Sada Cruzeiro
column25: accessdate=3 April 2020}}</ref> In both 2016 and 2017 he was one of the candidates to take over [[Poland men's national volleyball team]].<ref>{{cite web

column1: The '''Northern Combat Area Command''' or '''NCAC''' was a subcommand of the [[Allies of World War II
column2: Allied]] [[South East Asia Command]] (SEAC) during [[World War II]]. It controlled Allied ground operations in northern [[Burma]]. For most of its existence NCAC was commanded by [[United States Army
column4: Joseph \"Vinegar Joe\" Stilwell]] (who concurrently held more senior command positions). In 1945 after Stilwell was recalled, his deputy, Lieutenant General [[Daniel Isom Sultan
column5: Daniel Sultan]], was promoted to and assumed command.

column2: Chinese National Army]] personnel constituted most of the combat units within NCAC.

column1: While it was initially intended that NCAC would operate as an integral part of the [[British 11th Army Group]], Stilwell refused to work under General [[George Giffard]] and was made subordinate to the Supreme Commander of SEAC, [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma
In 1942, Northern Combat Area Command was formed at [[Ramgarh Cantonment]], in India, from [[X Force]]:  units (including the [[Chinese 22nd Division
column3: 38th]] Divisions), which had [[Japanese capture of Burma
column4: retreated out of Burma]]. After its arrival in India, X Force was reinforced – eventually becoming the [[New 1st Army]] – a [[corps
column5: corps-level]] formation. It was re-equipped at [[United Kingdom
column6: British]] expense and re-trained by US Army instructors.

column2: campaigning season of early 1944]], NCAC was augmented with [[Merrill's Marauders]] – a brigade-sized formation created by the US Army for commando-type operations in Burma. During 1944, NCAC forced the [[Japanese 18th Division]] to retreat out of northern Burma and US Army engineering battalions, assisted by [[India]]n laborers built the [[Ledo Road]] – which joined the northern end of the [[Burma Road]] and reestablished [[line of communications
column3: communications]] between India and China. Towards the end of 1944, NCAC was reinforced by the [[British 36th Infantry Division]].

column1: In 1945, under Sultan's command, NCAC – which now included the Chinese [[New 6th Army]] – aided in the drive to retake the rest of Burma.

The main combat power of NCAC, at least in terms of numbers were its Chinese divisions. When British and Chinese forces had been bundled out of Burma at the start of 1942, some Chinese forces had been obliged to retreat to [[India]], rather than to [[China]]. It was from these formations that the genesis of NCAC came.

Many times during World War II, British and American commanders in India were frustrated by their Chinese allies. A combination of fickleness and over-centralisation by the Chinese [[generalissimo]], [[Chiang Kai-shek]] and the limited training of the Chinese forces meant that they often failed to live up to their potential. However, the Chinese forces in NCAC were considerably better than their contemporaries in China itself. Greater access to American equipment and training and less influence from the Chinese leadership meant the four Chinese divisions in NCAC could be trusted a great deal more in combat.

However, it was not only from NCAC's divisions that trouble sprang. Its first commander was an extremely controversial character. Stilwell had first been posted to China as Chief of Staff to Chiang Kai-shek. However, as the campaign in Burma developed, he also took on a role there. The [[United States Army
column2: US Army]] established the [[China Burma India Theater of World War II
column3: China Burma India Theater]] (CBI Theater), and placed Stilwell in command. The CBI Theater was not supposed to be an operational headquarters. It was merely supposed to be in charge of the administration of the American military formations in China, Burma and India. However, Stilwell often broke the [[command hierarchy
column4: chain of command]] and communicated directly with the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]] on operational matters, when all such communications were supposed to go to Admiral [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma
column5: Lord Mountbatten]] the [[South East Asia Command
column6: Supreme Allied Commander, South East Asia]] and also on taking operational control of NCAC through General [[George Giffard]] commander of [[British 11th Army Group

column1: The initial idea was that as General Stilwell would be commanding several Chinese divisions which would attack out of India from the West and with the large but amorphous Yunnan armies attacking out of China from the East, he would be commanding a large army. So his command should be placed under 11th Army Group at the same level as the [[British Fourteenth Army
column2: Fourteenth]] which was under the command of General [[William Slim]]. The attacks could then be co-ordinated at Army Group level.

Stilwell, however bitterly resisted [being under Giffard's command]. To watch Stilwell, when hard pressed, shift his opposition from one of the several strong-points he held by virtue of his numerous Allied, American and Chinese offices, to another was a lesson in mobile offensive-defence.

column1: At a meeting to sort out the operational chain of command for the three fronts in Burma, Stilwell astonished everyone by saying \"I am prepared to come under General  Slim's operational control until I get to [[Kamaing]]\".{{sfn
column4: p=207}} Rather than sack him, Mountbatten reluctantly agreed to this, but it was a dangerous compromise. It created a complicated chain of command where Slim theoretically had to report to two different commanders. Giffard for Fourteenth Army actions and Mountbatten for Stilwell's formations. Under a general less gifted than Slim this could have caused serious problems, if Slim had not been able to command Stilwell at an operational level without disagreement (which given Stilwell's proven track record was more than likely). But at an operational level Slim was able to work with Stilwell and \"this illogical command set-up worked surprisingly well\".{{sfn

column1: The reason why it was essential that there was one operational commander for the three fronts, North, Central and Southern, was so that the intended attacks in late 1944 could be co-ordinated to prevent the Japanese concentrating large numbers of reserves for a counterattack on any one front.

Stilwell thus had four different jobs to perform, which required him to be in different places at once. For example, as Chief of Staff to Chiang, he was often needed in [[Chungking]], the Chinese capital, and as Deputy Allied Supreme Commander he was needed at HQ South East Asia Command at [[Kandy]] in [[Ceylon]] and as NCAC commander he was required to be relatively near the frontline in Burma. His personality also caused problems. Stilwell clashed frequently with the commander of the 11th Army Group, General Giffard, and would not accept being under his command, instead insisting that NCAC came directly under the Supreme Commander. As Deputy Allied Supreme Commander he was Giffard's superior but as operational commander of NCAC Giffard was his superior, as the two men did not get on this inevitablely lead to conflict and confusion.

NCAC's first months were frustrating, as the time was for all Allied formations in the theater. Its first real success did not come until the 1943-44 campaigning season. The [[Chindits]] had been dropped behind enemy lines after the end of the 1943 monsoon to cause havoc by cutting communications. This they did, but the original operational plan failed for a number of reasons. In the end, they were sent northwards into NCAC's area of operations.

At the time, NCAC's main job was to capture the town of [[Myitkyina]], as a prelude to connecting the [[Ledo Road]] to the [[Burma Road]] and reestablishing land communications to China.  During the offensive, NCAC intelligence staff serving under General Stilwell repeatedly underestimated Japanese troop strength in Burma.{{sfn
column7: p=450}}  A thrust from the northwest by NCAC was meeting with some success, but Stilwell also needed to use the Chindits in his plan. However, he not only used them, but misused them. The Chindits were designed as a light raiding force, not as conventional infantry. They had negligible artillery support, and were much smaller in number than equivalent conventional formations. However, Stilwell insisted on using them as conventional infantry. He assigned them the task of [[Battle of Mogaung
column8: capturing Mogaung]] south of Myitkyina, which was strongly held by the Japanese. The Chindits succeeded in their task, but had horrendous casualties. Even then Stilwell was not finished. He demanded still further miracles from the Chindits and their commander Brigadier [[Walter David Alexander Lentaigne
column9: Lentaigne]]. Reduced to the equivalent of less than a battalion, the Chindits assisted in the final assault on Myitkyina before finally bein flown out to India as a completely broken force, almost to a man. The American equivalent of the Chindits, [[Merrill's Marauders]] also suffered from the same treatment during the campaign, consistently being asked to perform missions that were beyond their power without superhuman effort.

column1: After the fall of Myitkyina, only a small area of Japanese territory separated NCAC from the Chinese forces. As the 1944 monsoon ended, NCAC opened an offensive. It had been reinforced with the [[British 36th Infantry Division]], which gave it a considerably increased punch. However, the [[Thirty-Third Army (Japan)
column2: Japanese 33rd Army]] under General [[Masaki Honda]] performed a very creditable delaying action against the forces attacking them. The Japanese were outnumbered several times, but still managed to hold the Chinese forces at bay for several months. In the end, it was events on the main front further south that forced them to withdraw, as they were in danger of being cut off from their supply lines. 36th Division was used to support the left wing of the [[British Fourteenth Army
column3: Fourteenth Army]] under Lieutenant General [[William Slim]].

column1: In October 1944, due to personal disagreements with Chiang, Stilwell was recalled to the [[United States]] by [[Franklin D. Roosevelt
column2: President Roosevelt]]. His former role was split as was the CBI Theater:
Raymond Wheeler]] became Deputy Supreme Allied Commander South East Asia.
Albert Wedemeyer]] became Chief of Staff to ''Chiang Kai-shek'' and commander of the U.S. Forces, China Theater (USFCT).

column1: * Lieutenant General [[Daniel Isom Sultan]] was promoted from deputy commander of CBI to become commander of the U.S. Forces, India-Burma Theater (USFIBT) and commander of the NCAC.
His replacements were not only less abrasive characters, but as they each concentrated on one area there was less institutional conflict and confusion.
NCAC's main role in the last few months of the war was to support the British main offensive further south, and to further improve the Burma Road to allow more supplies to get into China.
After the war, NCAC was quickly disbanded. It had achieved its objectives, but the route to those objectives was strewn with command problems and missed opportunities.
* [[South-East Asian Theatre of World War II
*Tuchman, Barbara W. (2001). Stilwell and the American Experience in China, 1911–45, Grove Press, {{ISBN

column5: title=Stilwell and the American Experience in China, 1911-45

column1: *[[Jon Latimer]], \"''Burma: The Longest War''\" ; London: John Murray {{ISBN
column2: 978-0-7195-6576-2}} is the most recent and comprehensive study of the whole campaign, including a description of the command structure, the personalities and the campaign waged in the NCAC. See in particular chapters 13 and 20.
Slim, William]] (1956). \"''Defeat into Victory''\" is also available from  NY: Buccaneer Books {{ISBN
column6: 0-330-39066-X}}. Chapter XII \"The Northern Front\" gives the personal view by the British overall commander.

It had been reinforced with the [[British 36th Infantry Division]], which gave it a considerably increased punch. However, the [[Thirty-Third Army (Japan)
column2: Japanese 33rd Army]] under General [[Masaki Honda]] performed a very creditable delaying action against the forces attacking them. The Japanese were outnumbered several times, but still managed to hold the Chinese forces at bay for several months. In the end, it was events on the main front further south that forced them to withdraw, as they were in danger of being cut off from their supply lines. 36th Division was used to support the left wing of the [[British Fourteenth Army
column3: Fourteenth Army]] under Lieutenant General [[William Slim]].

column1: In October 1944, due to personal disagreements with Chiang, Stilwell was recalled to the [[United States]] by [[Franklin D. Roosevelt
column2: President Roosevelt]]. His former role was split as was the CBI Theater:
Raymond Wheeler]] became Deputy Supreme Allied Commander South East Asia.
Albert Wedemeyer]] became Chief of Staff to ''Chiang Kai-shek'' and commander of the U.S. Forces, China Theater (USFCT).

column1: * Lieutenant General [[Daniel Isom Sultan]] was promoted from deputy commander of CBI to become commander of the U.S. Forces, India-Burma Theater (USFIBT) and commander of the NCAC.
His replacements were not only less abrasive characters, but as they each concentrated on one area there was less institutional conflict and confusion.
NCAC's main role in the last few months of the war was to support the British main offensive further south, and to further improve the Burma Road to allow more supplies to get into China.
After the war, NCAC was quickly disbanded. It had achieved its objectives, but the route to those objectives was strewn with command problems and missed opportunities.
* [[South-East Asian Theatre of World War II
*Tuchman, Barbara W. (2001). Stilwell and the American Experience in China, 1911–45, Grove Press, {{ISBN

column5: title=Stilwell and the American Experience in China, 1911-45

column1: *[[Jon Latimer]], \"''Burma: The Longest War''\" ; London: John Murray {{ISBN
column2: 978-0-7195-6576-2}} is the most recent and comprehensive study of the whole campaign, including a description of the command structure, the personalities and the campaign waged in the NCAC. See in particular chapters 13 and 20.
Slim, William]] (1956). \"''Defeat into Victory''\" is also available from  NY: Buccaneer Books {{ISBN
column6: 0-330-39066-X}}. Chapter XII \"The Northern Front\" gives the personal view by the British overall commander.

column2: German war crime – massacre during World War II}}

column3: The barn set on fire in the Gardelegen Massacre]]

column1: The '''Gardelegen  massacre''' was a [[massacre]] perpetrated by the German local population from [[Volkssturm]], [[Hitlerjugend]] and local firefighters with minor direction from the [[Schutzstaffel
column2: SS]] during [[World War II]]. On April 13, 1945, on the Isenschnibbe estate near the [[North Germany
column3: northern German]] town of [[Gardelegen]], the troops forced 1,016 slave laborers who were part of a transport evacuated from the [[Mittelbau-Dora]] Concentration Camp and from the Hannover-Stöcken Concentration Camp into a large barn which was then set on fire.

column1: 1016 prisoners, of which the largest group were Poles, were burned alive or shot trying to escape. The crime was discovered two days later by F Company, 2nd Battalion, 405th Regiment, [[U.S. 102nd Infantry Division]], when the U.S. Army occupied the area. Eleven prisoners were found alive – 7 Poles, 3 Russians and 1 Frenchman. The testimonies of survivors were collected and published by Melchior Wańkowicz in 1969, in the book ''From Stołpców to Cairo''. Gardelegen became a part of the newly established [[German Democratic Republic]] in 1947 and is now in [[Saxony-Anhalt]], Germany.
[[File:Gardelegen Massacre, Soldiers in barn viewing bodies, Charles Overstreet.jpg
column3: American soldiers view bodies in barn]]

column2: image1    = Political prisoners of the Nazis who met their deaths at the hands of SS troops who set the barn afire. This group... - NARA - 531268.tif
caption1  = Prisoner who attempted to escape conflagration

column3: Under the direction of an American soldier, German civilians from Gardelegen carry wooden crosses to the site where they were ordered to bury the bodies of concentration camp prisoners killed by the SS in a barn just outside the town]]

column1: The discovery of the massacre seems to have been by chance.  The consensus account is that American [[Lieutenant]] Emerson Hunt, a liaison officer <!--(____unit____)--> between Ozark HQ and the 701st Tank Battalion, was captured by German forces on April 14, 1945, that he bluffed the German forces defending the town of Gardelegen into believing that American tanks were approaching the city, and that this induced the German commander to surrender to the American forces.  The Americans arrived at the site before the Germans had time to bury all of the bodies.<ref>https://archive.org/stream/with102dinfantry00unit/with102dinfantry00unit_djvu.txt</ref>
On April 3–4, following the [[United States Army
column2: U.S. Army]]'s crossing of the [[Rhine River]] and push into [[Germany]], the [[SS]] camp administration at [[Dora-Mittelbau]] had ordered the evacuation of prisoners from the main camp and a number of its affiliated subcamps. The goal was to transport the inmates by train or by foot to the other north German concentration camps: [[Bergen-Belsen concentration camp

column1: Within days, some 4,000 prisoners from Mittelbau-Dora, its satellite camps, and from the Neuengamme subcamp Hannover-Stöcken arrived in the Gardelegen area, where they had to deboard from the freight cars because the trains could not advance any further due to air raid damage to the rail lines. Greatly outnumbered by the prisoners, the SS guards began recruiting auxiliary forces from the local fire department, the air force, the aged [[Volkssturm
column2: home guard]], the [[Hitler Youth]], and other organizations to watch over the inmates.

column1: On April 13, more than a thousand prisoners, many of them sick and too weak to march any further, were taken from the town of Gardelegen to a large barn on the [[Isenschnibbe]] estate and forced inside the building. The assembled guards then barricaded the doors and set fire to gasoline-soaked straw. Prisoners who escaped the conflagration by digging under the barn's walls were killed by the guards. The next day, the SS and local auxiliaries returned to dispose of the evidence of their crime. They planned to incinerate what remained of the bodies and the barn, and kill any survivors of the blaze. The swift advance of the [[102nd Infantry Division (United States)]], however, prevented the SS and its accomplices from completely carrying out this plan.

On April 14, the 102nd entered Gardelegen and, the following day, discovered the atrocity. They found the corpses of 1,016 prisoners in the still-smoldering barn and nearby trenches, where the SS had had the charred remains dumped. They also interviewed several of the prisoners who had managed to escape the fire and the shootings. [[U.S. Army Signal Corps]] photographers soon arrived to document the Nazi crime and by April 19, 1945, the story of the Gardelegen massacre began appearing in the Western press. On that day, both the ''[[New York Times]]'' and ''[[The Washington Post]]'' ran stories on the massacre, quoting one American soldier who stated:

I never was so sure before of exactly what I was fighting for. Before this you would have said those stories were [[propaganda]], but now you know they weren't. There are the bodies and all those guys are dead.
Eleven prisoners survived the burning of the barn and were found alive by U.S. soldiers – seven Poles, three Russians and one severely wounded Frenchman.

On April 21, 1945, the local commander of the 102nd ordered between 200 and 300 men from the town of Gardelegen to give the murdered prisoners a proper burial. Over the next few days, the German civilians exhumed 586 bodies from the trenches and recovered 430 bodies from the barn, placing each in an individual grave. On April 25, the 102nd carried out a ceremony to honor the dead and erected a memorial tablet to the victims, which stated that the townspeople of Gardelegen are charged with the responsibility that the “graves are forever kept as green as the memory of these unfortunates will be kept in the hearts of freedom-loving men everywhere.” Also on April 25, Colonel George Lynch addressed German civilians at Gardelegen with the following statement:

The German people have been told that stories of German atrocities were Allied propaganda. Here, you can see for yourself. Some will say that the Nazis were responsible for this crime. Others will point to the Gestapo. The responsibility rests with neither — it is the responsibility of the German people....Your so-called Master Race has demonstrated that it is master only of crime, cruelty and sadism. You have lost the respect of the civilized world.
An investigation was undertaken by Lieutenant Colonel [[Edward E. Cruise]], Investigating Officer, [[U.S. Ninth Army
Text of Lieutenant Colonel Cruise's report and text of other exhibits are stored in US Army file 000-12-242.

column3: de}}, the transport leader for the prisoners evacuated from the Mittelbau-Dora concentration camp who subsequently wound up in Gardelegen, was put on trial in 1947 before [[Dachau Trials
column4: a US military tribunal]] and was sentenced to life in prison. He died in 1950.

column1: Statements of the survivors were gathered by Polish writer [[Melchior Wańkowicz]] and published in 1969.
[[File:Mahn- und Gedenkstätte Isenschnibber Feldscheune - Bestehende Feldscheunenfront.jpg
column3: The surviving wall of the barn]]

column1: [[File:Mahn- und Gedenkstätte Isenschnibber Feldscheune - Buch der Opfer vor dem Friedhof.JPG
Gardelegen is now a national memorial, which was rearranged by the former [[Eastern Germany
The sign at the cemetery, founded by the U.S. Army, reads:
war who were murdered by their
They were buried by citizens of
ever kept as green as the memory
of these unfortunates will be kept
in the hearts of freedom-loving men
Vandalism will be punished by maximum
The sign at the remaining wall of the barn, applied by officials of the German Democratic Republic, reads:

You stand in front of the ruins of a barn, where one of the most cruel crimes of fascism was taking place. In the night of their liberation, a few hours before Allied forces approach, 1016 international fighters of resistance against facism were brutally and inhumanely burned alive. Whenever you feel apathy or weakness in fighting against facism and imperialistic threat of war, get new power from our unforgettable dead.

The memorial is located at the historic scene of the massacre of Gardelegen. It is a reminder of the 1016 concentration camp prisoners from many European countries who were murdered there on 13 April 1945 in a field barn near the Hanseatic city of Gardelegen. The site also includes the Memorial Cemetery, where the victims of the massacre are buried.

A visitor and documentation center with a permanent exhibition is being built on the site in 2018.<ref>https://gedenkstaette-gardelegen.sachsen-anhalt.de/fileadmin/Bibliothek/STGS/Isenschnibbe_Gardelegen/Flyer_Gardelegen_en.pdf</ref>

* Diana Gring: Die Todesmärsche und das Massaker von Gardelegen – NS-Verbrechen in der Endphase des Zweiten Weltkrieges, Gardelegen 1993.

Die Auflösung des KZ Neuengamme und seiner Außenlager durch die SS im Frühjahr 1945, Bremen 2005, {{ISBN

column2: description     = Large, furry, orange creature in Flyers regalia

column1: '''Gritty''' is the official mascot for the [[Philadelphia Flyers]] [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) team. He has COVID-19. He is a {{convert
column4: adj=on}} furry orange creature with [[googly eyes]] who wears Flyers' gear.<ref>{{Cite news
column6: title=Flyers introduce new 'Gritty' addition to team
column11: title=The Internet Thinks the Philadelphia Flyers' New Mascot Named 'Gritty' Is a Nightmare
column14: language=en-us}}</ref> Gritty has been compared to the [[Phillie Phanatic]], the mascot for the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] baseball team.<ref name=\":1\" /> He was created by Brian Allen of Flyland Designs with help from David Raymond, the first man to portray the Phillie Phanatic.<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=I'm David Raymond, Creator of Gritty, and This Is How I Work
column19: accessdate=October 10, 2018}}</ref> Gritty was introduced on September 24, 2018.<ref>{{cite news
column25: accessdate=October 3, 2018}}</ref> According to his official biography, Gritty emerged after construction at the [[Wells Fargo Center (Philadelphia)
column26: Wells Fargo Center]], the Flyers' home arena, disturbed his secret hideout.<ref>{{cite web
column30: accessdate=January 8, 2019}}</ref> Within the months following his debut, he became an internet sensation and made appearances on several talk shows.<ref name=\"BBC\">{{cite news
column32: title=Gritty: How a NHL mascot became an internet sensation

column1: Prior to Gritty's debut, the Flyers were only one of two NHL teams without an official mascot, the other being the [[New York Rangers]].<ref name=\"NYT\">{{cite news
column5: title=Gritty's First Month: The Heroic Ascendance of a 'Ghastly Empty-Eyed Muppet'
column8: accessdate=November 1, 2018}}</ref> The team previously had a mascot named Slapshot, but it only lasted one season, in 1976.<ref name=\"USA Today\">{{cite news
column10: title=Gettin' Gritty Wit It: Flyers new mascot a big hit
column14: \"Slapshot\"]] name now belongs to the mascot of the Flyers' division rival, the [[Washington Capitals]].

column1: The impetus for Gritty's creation was when the Flyers' marketing department attended the mascot events at the [[2016 National Hockey League All-Star Game
column2: 2016 NHL All-Star Game]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], and realized that they were missing out on all the marketing and community outreach programs that the league's mascots were generating for their respective teams.<ref name=\"USA Today\"/> The Flyers then commissioned Brian Allen of Flyland Designs in [[Bellefonte, Pennsylvania]], to design Gritty in August 2018.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Philadelphia Flyers’ new mascot, ‘Gritty,’ designed by Belleofnte’s Brian Allen | Centre Daily Times
column12: title=Bellefonte man helps create Philadelphia Flyer's new mascot
column15: accessdate=October 28, 2018}}</ref> David Raymond, who portrayed the Phillie Phanatic, consulted on Gritty's creation.<ref>{{Cite web
column17: title=Gritty, the Flyers’ new mascot, is set up for success. (According to the Phillie Phanatic, anyway.)

column1: The Flyers organization wanted Gritty to have a rather intimidating appearance, as \"someone you'd high-five but not hug\" according to Allen.<ref name=\"NYT\" />
Gritty made his debut on September 24, 2018, and appeared on the [[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon
column2: ''Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon'']] several days later.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite news
column4: title=NHL mascot rankings: Gritty's big debut
column9: title=LOOK: New Flyers mascot Gritty dances with Jimmy Fallon, gets punched by Ricky Gervais

column1: Many sources brought attention to his appearance, which could be construed as frightening,<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite news
column3: title=Meet Gritty: The Flyers' new team mascot
column7: language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=\":0\" /> while ''The Guardian'' described him as an \"[[Psychedelic experience
column8: acid trip]] of a mascot.\"<ref>{{Cite news
column10: title=Gritty: why the Philadelphia Flyers' new acid trip of a mascot must be stopped
column17: issn=0261-3077}}</ref> Gritty was lampooned on ''[[Last Week Tonight with John Oliver]]'' and ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=John Oliver compares Brett Kavanaugh to Flyers mascot Gritty on ‘Last Week Tonight’
column26: title='Saturday Night Live's' Weekend Update takes its shot at Gritty
column29: accessdate=October 28, 2018}}</ref> He was re-appropriated as a [[socialist]] and [[Antifa (United States)
column30: antifa]] meme in a manner similar to how [[Pepe the Frog]] was re-appropriated by various [[alt-right]] groups.<ref name=\"NYT\"/> In response, Sarah Schwab, director of marketing for the team, said Gritty was never intended to represent anything political, and that he was never left-wing or right-wing as he \"doesn't know his right from his left\".<ref name=\"NYT\"/>

column1: Response to Gritty's introduction was immediate and sharply mixed, with many fans on social media expressing bewilderment and some fright at his appearance.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=It's Gritty! Philadelphia Flyers New Mascot is Pure Unadulterated Nightmare Fuel
column8: accessdate=October 11, 2019}}</ref> Public perception of Gritty became increasingly positive as Gritty's antics, which subverted the cuddly, family-friendly appearance and demeanor of other NHL mascots, gained more attention on social media.<ref name=\"Jeremy Schneider\">{{cite web
column10: title= 9 Ridiculous Things Gritty, the Flyers' New Insane Mascot, has Already Done
column13: accessdate=October 11, 2019}}</ref> On September 24, 2018, a few minutes after Gritty's debut, Gritty appeared to threaten longtime Flyers [[Flyers–Penguins rivalry
column16: title=Gritty on Twitter: \"Sleep with one eye open tonight, bird.… \"
column18: website=web.archive.org}}</ref> In his first on-ice appearance, Gritty fell while firing T-shirts into the crowd from a T-shirt cannon.<ref name=\"Jeremy Schneider\"/> In his second appearance on ice, Gritty body-checked contestants in a goalie race during an intermission and shot a Flyers staff member with a T-shirt cannon.<ref name=\"Jeremy Schneider\"/><ref>{{cite web

column1: Shortly after his debut, the residents of Philadelphia began to embrace Gritty.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=What is Gritty? A 'lovable monster,' the orange embodiment of Philly and the Flyers, or a brand marketing breakthrough?
column7: accessdate=October 28, 2018}}</ref> On October 24, 2018, the [[Philadelphia City Council]] passed a formal resolution honoring Gritty, declaring that he honored the city's spirit and passion.<ref name=\"NYT\"/><ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Gritty, Stuff Of Nightmares, Has Been Officially Welcomed To Philadelphia

column1: In November 2018, [[BBC News]] reported that Gritty had amassed almost 200,000 [[Twitter]] followers.<ref name=\"BBC\"/>
On March 20, 2019 it was announced the NHL Player's Association had voted Gritty the number one mascot in the league.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Gritty voted NHL’s Best Team Mascot | WPMT FOX43

column1: On October 13, 2019 the first ever “Gritty anti-runners 5K” took place. This 5K race included Gritty’s favorite things along the track, including hot dogs, silly string, and a shrine to [[Claude Giroux]].<ref>{{cite web

In November 2019 during a fan meet-and-greet between Gritty and Flyers [[season ticket]] holders, a fan reported that the Flyers employee portraying Gritty punched their 13 year old son in the back. After an internal investigation by the Flyers led to no other witnesses of such abuse, the fan reported the incident to the [[Philadelphia Police Department]], which has led to its own investigation. On February 3, 2020, the Flyers employee portraying Gritty was officially cleared of any wrongdoing and charges were declined to be filed following an investigation conducted by the South Detectives Division of the Philadelphia Police Department.<ref>https://www.inquirer.com/business/comcast/flyers-gritty-assault-boy-philadelphia-police-investigation-20200122.html</ref><ref>https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2020/01/22/gritty-flyers-mascot-philadelphia-police-investigating-claim-physically-assaulted-teen-boy-during-photo-shoot/</ref><ref>https://www.broadstreethockey.com/2020/1/23/21078804/everyone-is-talking-about-gritty-philadelphia-flyers-mascot-lawsuit</ref>

column5: title=Liberté, Egalité, Gritté: how an NHL mascot became an antifa hero

column2: description     = Large, furry, orange creature in Flyers regalia

column1: '''Gritty''' is the official mascot for the [[Philadelphia Flyers]] [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) team. He is a {{convert
column4: adj=on}} furry orange creature with [[googly eyes]] who wears Flyers' gear.<ref>{{Cite news
column6: title=Flyers introduce new 'Gritty' addition to team
column11: title=The Internet Thinks the Philadelphia Flyers' New Mascot Named 'Gritty' Is a Nightmare
column14: language=en-us}}</ref> Gritty has been compared to the [[Phillie Phanatic]], the mascot for the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] baseball team.<ref name=\":1\" /> He was created by Brian Allen of Flyland Designs with help from David Raymond, the first man to portray the Phillie Phanatic.<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=I'm David Raymond, Creator of Gritty, and This Is How I Work
column19: accessdate=October 10, 2018}}</ref> Gritty was introduced on September 24, 2018.<ref>{{cite news
column25: accessdate=October 3, 2018}}</ref> According to his official biography, Gritty emerged after construction at the [[Wells Fargo Center (Philadelphia)
column26: Wells Fargo Center]], the Flyers' home arena, disturbed his secret hideout.<ref>{{cite web
column30: accessdate=January 8, 2019}}</ref> Within the months following his debut, he became an internet sensation and made appearances on several talk shows.<ref name=\"BBC\">{{cite news
column32: title=Gritty: How a NHL mascot became an internet sensation

column1: Prior to Gritty's debut, the Flyers were only one of two NHL teams without an official mascot, the other being the [[New York Rangers]].<ref name=\"NYT\">{{cite news
column5: title=Gritty's First Month: The Heroic Ascendance of a 'Ghastly Empty-Eyed Muppet'
column8: accessdate=November 1, 2018}}</ref> The team previously had a mascot named Slapshot, but it only lasted one season, in 1976.<ref name=\"USA Today\">{{cite news
column10: title=Gettin' Gritty Wit It: Flyers new mascot a big hit
column14: \"Slapshot\"]] name now belongs to the mascot of the Flyers' division rival, the [[Washington Capitals]].

column1: The impetus for Gritty's creation was when the Flyers' marketing department attended the mascot events at the [[2016 National Hockey League All-Star Game
column2: 2016 NHL All-Star Game]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], and realized that they were missing out on all the marketing and community outreach programs that the league's mascots were generating for their respective teams.<ref name=\"USA Today\"/> The Flyers then commissioned Brian Allen of Flyland Designs in [[Bellefonte, Pennsylvania]], to design Gritty in August 2018.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Philadelphia Flyers’ new mascot, ‘Gritty,’ designed by Belleofnte’s Brian Allen | Centre Daily Times
column12: title=Bellefonte man helps create Philadelphia Flyer's new mascot
column15: accessdate=October 28, 2018}}</ref> David Raymond, who portrayed the Phillie Phanatic, consulted on Gritty's creation.<ref>{{Cite web
column17: title=Gritty, the Flyers’ new mascot, is set up for success. (According to the Phillie Phanatic, anyway.)

column1: The Flyers organization wanted Gritty to have a rather intimidating appearance, as \"someone you'd high-five but not hug\" according to Allen.<ref name=\"NYT\" />
Gritty made his debut on September 24, 2018, and appeared on the [[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon
column2: ''Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon'']] several days later.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite news
column4: title=NHL mascot rankings: Gritty's big debut
column9: title=LOOK: New Flyers mascot Gritty dances with Jimmy Fallon, gets punched by Ricky Gervais

column2: image               = Drowning Pool at Fort Wainwright 2010 Ryan McCombs 3.jpg

column3: title= What is UR Favorite Classic Nu-Metal Band??

column1: '''Soil''' – often typeset as '''SOiL''' – is an American [[Rock music
column2: rock]] band that was formed in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] in 1997.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2020-01-19}}</ref> After some independent releases, the band was the first rock group signed to [[J Records]] and achieved mainstream success with their major label debut, ''[[Scars (Soil album)
column8: Scars]]'', in 2001. The J Records second album ''[[Redefine (Soil album)
column9: Redefine]]'' was released in 2004 and the band embarked upon a worldwide tour to follow. In late 2004 frontman [[Ryan McCombs]] left the group. He would go on to become the new vocalist of [[Drowning Pool]] the following year.

column1: The band recruited ex- Diesel Machine vocalist [[A Cavalier
column2: AJ Cavalier]] as its new singer and released two more studio albums (True Self, Picture Perfect) through independent labels in 2006 and 2009 respectively. SOiL continued to tour worldwide and met with strong independent success. The band had brief line-up changes until in fall 2011, Soil reunited with Ryan McCombs for a tour commemorating the tenth anniversary of their landmark album, ''Scars''. The line-up is currently completed with fellow original members Tim King (Bass) and Adam Zadel (Guitar), who are the only two members to have stayed with the band from inception until present. The band has sold over two million records worldwide and released its sixth studio album, entitled ''Whole'', on August 20, 2013 (August 16 UK/Europe).

column1: The band released a greatest hits album, titled Scream: The Essentials on September 15, 2017

Soil was originally formed in 1997 by three of four members of [[death metal]] act [[Oppressor]], joined by guitarist of another death metal act [[Broken Hope]] – as a side project to their other bands. Ryan McCombs was later recruited for vocal duties.

The original line-up of the band was Ryan McCombs (vocals), Shaun Glass (Broken Hope), Tom Schofield, Tim King, and Adam Zadel (all three ex-Oppressor). The band got its name from the Entombed song \"Rotten Soil\" by opting to simply drop the \"Rotten\" part and stick with \"Soil\".

column4: El Chupacabra]]'' (EP) and their debut album ''[[Throttle Junkies]]'', failed to break the band into the mainstream. It was around this time that all the members of Soil left their other bands to focus on Soil as their main project.

column1: With the song \"Halo\" gaining major radio attention, labels began a bidding war for a deal with Soil. The band would ultimately be signed to J Records by music industry legend [[Clive Davis]], responsible for signing such acts as [[Pink Floyd]] and [[Bruce Springsteen]], who stated that \"you're gonna be my only rock band for now. You're going to be a priority, and I want to break this band.\"<ref name=\"OMH\">{{cite web
column8: accessdate = 26 February 2012}}</ref> Soil finally experienced mainstream success with the [[major label]] debut, ''[[Scars (Soil album)
column9: Scars]]'', released September 11, 2001.<ref name=OMH/> This achievement was aided by the popular singles \"Halo\" and \"Unreal\" which gained the band exposure on [[MTV]]. The success resulted in the band winning [[Metal Edge]] magazine's 2001 Readers' Choice Award for \"Next Big Thing\".<ref>Metal Edge, June 2002</ref>

column1: In 2004, the band released their second major label album, ''[[Redefine (Soil album)
column2: Redefine]]''. The group toured for a year in support of the album and returned home to begin writing follow up material and finish various live dates.  Shortly after, vocalist [[Ryan McCombs]] announced his departure from the group to be with his family,<ref name=OMH/> forcing the band to cancel scheduled shows. [[New York City
column3: New York]]-based vocalist [[AJ Cavalier]], previously of World In Pain and Diesel Machine, was introduced on November 15, 2004 as McCombs' replacement. On July 20, 2005, McCombs was confirmed to be the new singer for Drowning Pool.

column1: On September 21, 2005, Soil signed with New York-based [[independent label]] [[DRT Entertainment]]. Their album ''[[True Self]]'' was released on May 2, 2006. The album leaked onto [[Peer-to-peer file sharing
column3: BitTorrent]] sites on March 4, almost two months before its official release. SOiL embarked upon a very heavy worldwide touring schedule to promote the release. In November 2007, Shaun Glass parted ways with the band, citing personal and musical differences.

column1: On October 20, 2009 the album ''[[Picture Perfect (Soil album)
column2: Picture Perfect]]'' was released via Bieler Bros Records worldwide, except in Europe, where it was released by AFM Records. ''Picture Perfect'' was produced by Johnny K (Disturbed, Staind), Ulrich Wild (Deftones, Incubus) and Soil, with Dave Fortman (Mudvayne, Evanescence) handling mixing duties. It was promoted with the lead single, \"Like It Is.\" In January 2010, \"The Lesser Man\" was announced as a second single.

column1: On July 23, 2010, vocalist A.J. Cavalier, and drummer Tom Schofield announced their departure from the band.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=BLABBERMOUTH.NET – SOIL Singer On 'Indefinite Hiatus' From Band; Drummer Seeking 'New Musical Opportunities'
column6: accessdate=25 November 2018}}</ref> Vocalist Jordan Lee and drummer Mike Tignino were announced as fill-ins for scheduled live dates.<ref>[http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=143442 It's Official: SOIL Recruits 'Fill-In' Singer, Drummer For Upcoming Shows] {{webarchive

column1: The band reunited with original vocalist Ryan McCombs for a 12-date co-headlining UK tour with [[Puddle of Mudd]] in October 2011 to celebrate the 10th anniversary of ''Scars''. Former [[Staind]] drummer Jon Wysocki also joined Soil for the 2011 UK Tour.
Sony Music UK announced in 2011 that ''Scars'' has been certified silver in the UK with sales in excess of over 60,000 units.

Soil added several US tour dates throughout 2012. The trek will be the band's first in the US since original frontman Ryan McCombs rejoined the group.<ref>[http://rockaccess.net/2011/12/19/soil-announce-u-s-tour-dates/ SOiL Announce U.S. Tour Dates] {{webarchive

SOiL's first ever DVD entitled \"Re-LIVE-ing The Scars\" was released May 8, 2012. The DVD/CD combo was recorded live in London, England during the bands sold out 2011 UK tour and features the first live show with vocalist Ryan McCombs in 7 years.  The DVD also includes bonus footage and photo gallery.

column2: Whole]]'' was released Aug 16, 2013 (worldwide) and Aug 20, 2013 (North America). The album was funded through [[Kickstarter]]. The band released music video and single for \"Shine On\" on June 25, 2013. The second single \"The Hate Song\" was released in 2014. The third single \"Way Gone\" was released in 2015.

column1: SOiL released the compilation album \"SCREAM: The Essentials\" on September 15, 2017 via Pavement/AFM Records. This compilation album features the band's hits along with alternate versions and unreleased material, and includes a cover of \"[[Gimme Some Lovin']]\" by The Spencer Davis Group<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=SOIL To Release 'Scream: The Essentials' In September

column1: * A.J. Cavalier – lead vocals <small>(2004–2010)</small>, rhythm guitar <small>(2007–2010) </small>
[[Category:Musical groups established in 1997]]","{{Infobox musical artist  <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->

column2: Defensive play made by NY Giant Willie Mays in Game 1 of the 1954 World Series}}

column4: fly ball]] on the [[warning track]] in the [[1954 World Series]].]]

column1: '''The Catch''' was a [[baseball]] play made by [[San Francisco Giants
column2: New York Giants]] center fielder [[Willie Mays]] on September 29, 1954, during Game 1 of the [[1954 World Series]] at the [[Polo Grounds]] in [[Upper Manhattan
column3: Upper Manhattan, New York City]]. During the eighth [[inning]] with the score tied 2–2, [[1954 Cleveland Indians season
column4: Cleveland Indians]] batter [[Vic Wertz]] hit a deep [[Batted ball
column6: center field]] that was poised to score the [[Base running
column7: runners on base]]. However, Mays made an over-the-shoulder [[Catch (baseball)
column8: catch]] while on the run to record the [[Out (baseball)
column9: out]], and his throw back to the [[Infield#Baseball
column10: infield]] prevented the runners from advancing. The Giants won the game 5–2 in [[extra innings]], and eventually the World Series. The Catch is regarded as one of the greatest plays in baseball history.

column1: In the top of the 8th inning with the score tied 2–2,<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Flashback: Willie Mays makes 'The Catch' in 1954 World Series
column9: accessdate=June 22, 2016}}</ref> Giants starting [[pitcher]] [[Sal Maglie]] [[base on balls
column10: walked]] Indians lead off hitter [[Larry Doby]]. [[Al Rosen]] singled, putting [[baserunning
column11: runners]] on first and second.<ref name=retrosheet>{{cite web
column17: manager]] [[Leo Durocher]] summoned left-handed [[relief pitcher]] [[Don Liddle]] to pitch to Cleveland's Wertz, a left-handed batter.<ref name=retrosheet/>

column1: Wertz worked the count to two balls and one strike before hitting Liddle's fourth pitch approximately {{convert
column4: m}} to deep center field. In many stadiums the ball would have been a [[home run]], which would have given the Indians a 5–2 lead. However, the Polo Grounds center field was larger than average, and Mays, who was playing in shallow center field, made an on-the-run, over-the-shoulder catch at the [[warning track]] for the out. Having caught the ball, he immediately spun and threw the ball. Doby, the runner on second, might have been able to score the go-ahead run had he tagged at the moment the ball was caught; as it was, he ran when the ball was hit, then had to scramble back to tag. Mays' throw went to second base, holding Cleveland to runners at second and third with one out.<ref name=retrosheet/>

column1: Right-hander [[Marv Grissom]] then relieved Liddle,<ref name=retrosheet/> who supposedly remarked to [[coach (baseball)
column2: coach]] [[Freddie Fitzsimmons]], \"Well, I got ''my'' man.\"<ref>{{cite book
column6: title=Baseball Myths: Debating, Debunking, and Disproving Tales from the Diamond
column12: Dale Mitchell]] to load the bases, then struck out pinch hitter [[Dave Pope]], and got catcher [[Jim Hegan]] to fly out, ending the inning with no runs scored.<ref name=retrosheet/>

column4: Mays and Polo Grounds center field distance marker.]]

column1: [[Jack Brickhouse]], calling the game on television for [[Major League Baseball on NBC
column2: NBC]], along with [[Russ Hodges]], described Mays' catch to viewers. The audio has been published on [[compact disc
column3: CD]] with the book ''And the Fans Roared'',<ref name=FansRoared>{{cite book
column8: title=And the Fans Roared: The Sports Broadcasts That Kept Us on the Edge of Our Seats
column13: url=https://www.amazon.com/Fans-Roared-Sports-Broadcasts-Seats/dp/1570715823/}}</ref> and also as accompaniment to the World Series film.

column1: '''Brickhouse''': There's a long drive... way back at center field... way back, back, it is a... Oh my! Caught by Mays!<ref name=FansRoared/>{{rp
column2: 16}} The runner on second, Doby, is able to go to third.<ref>{{cite AV media
column7: time=0:52 of Track 5}}</ref> Willie Mays just brought this crowd to its feet with a catch which must have been an optical illusion to a lot of people!<ref name=FansRoared/>{{rp
column8: 17}} Boy! [pause] Notice where that 483 foot mark is in center field? The ball itself—Russ, you know this ballpark better than anyone else I know—had to go about 460,{{efn

column1: '''Hodges''': It certainly did, and I don't see how Willie did it, but he's been doing it all year.<ref>{{cite AV media
'''Brickhouse''': Willie Mays just made the catch of the day.<ref>{{cite AV media
There is some question of the depth of straight-away center field. Sometimes there was a 475{{efn
column5: m}}}} sign in center field, sometimes 483{{efn
column9: m}}}} (as was the case in 1954).<ref name=lowry/> The ballpark was demolished in 1964, and it is unclear what was being measured when. One theory is that 475 was the distance to the front of the clubhouse overhang, and 483 was the distance to the rear wall under the overhang.<ref name=lowry>{{cite book
column12: title=Green Cathedrals: The Ultimate Celebrations of All 273 Major League and Negro League Ballparks Past and Present
column18: url-access=registration }}</ref> Regardless, the ball was not hit to the deepest part of center field; where Mays made his catch is estimated by baseball researchers as not more than {{convert
column26: title=Catching up with Vic Wertz's 1954 World Series Drive

column4: The baseball glove that Willie Mays used in \"the catch\" on display at the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum]] in 2008.]]

column1: The play prevented the Indians from taking the lead and, in the bottom of the 10th, the Giants won the game on their way to sweeping the Series. The Catch is often considered to be one of the best and most memorable plays in the history of baseball because of the difficulty of the play and the importance of the game itself.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Happy 60th Anniversary: Willie Mays makes 'The Catch'

column1: Mays himself did not believe \"The Catch\" to be the best defensive play he ever made.<ref>{{cite news
column18: via=newspapers.com}}</ref> In the CD collection ''[[Ernie Harwell]]'s Audio Scrapbook'', issued in 2006,<ref name=Harwell>{{cite book
column26: url=https://www.amazon.com/Ernie-Harwells-Audio-Scrapbook-Harwell/dp/0979212006/}}</ref> Mays talks about a running ''bare-handed'' catch he made at [[Forbes Field]] in [[Pittsburgh]] in 1951, in which the Giants' players teased the young rookie by treating him with complete indifference when he returned to the bench.<ref name=Harwell /> Mays also cited a catch he made against the center field wall at [[Ebbets Field]] in [[Brooklyn
column27: Brooklyn, New York]], in which he had to scurry back so fast he did not have time to turn around.<ref name=Harwell />  Other observers have noted that Mays' quick relay throw from deep center field was the most important part of the 1954 play, the catch itself being merely a matter of Mays outrunning the ball.<ref name=Harwell />

column1: In 2007, a [[physicist]] calculated that if the temperature had been {{convert
column7: C}}, the ball would have traveled {{convert
column10: cm}} farther than it did, and The Catch might not have been completed.<ref name=\"npr\">{{cite news

column2: Defensive play made by NY Giant Willie Mays in Game 1 of the 1954 World Series}}

column1: '''The Catch''' was a [[baseball]] play made by [[San Francisco Giants
column2: New York Giants]] center fielder [[Willie Mays]] on September 29, 1954, during Game 1 of the [[1954 World Series]] at the [[Polo Grounds]] in [[Upper Manhattan
column3: Upper Manhattan, New York City]]. During the eighth [[inning]] with the score tied 2–2, [[1954 Cleveland Indians season
column4: Cleveland Indians]] batter [[Vic Wertz]] hit a deep [[Batted ball
column6: center field]] that was poised to score the [[Base running
column7: runners on base]]. However, Mays made an over-the-shoulder [[Catch (baseball)
column8: catch]] while on the run to record the [[Out (baseball)
column9: out]], and his throw back to the [[Infield#Baseball
column10: infield]] prevented the runners from advancing. The Giants won the game 5–2 in [[extra innings]], and eventually the World Series. The Catch is regarded as one of the greatest plays in baseball history.

column1: In the top of the 8th inning with the score tied 2–2,<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Flashback: Willie Mays makes 'The Catch' in 1954 World Series
column9: accessdate=June 22, 2016}}</ref> Giants starting [[pitcher]] [[Sal Maglie]] [[base on balls
column10: walked]] Indians lead off hitter [[Larry Doby]]. [[Al Rosen]] singled, putting [[baserunning
column11: runners]] on first and second.<ref name=retrosheet>{{cite web
column17: manager]] [[Leo Durocher]] summoned left-handed [[relief pitcher]] [[Don Liddle]] to pitch to Cleveland's Wertz, a left-handed batter.<ref name=retrosheet/>

However, the Polo Grounds center field was larger than average, and Mays, who was playing in shallow center field, made an on-the-run, over-the-shoulder catch at the [[warning track]] for the out. Having caught the ball, he immediately spun and threw the ball. Doby, the runner on second, might have been able to score the go-ahead run had he tagged at the moment the ball was caught; as it was, he ran when the ball was hit, then had to scramble back to tag. Mays' throw went to second base, holding Cleveland to runners at second and third with one out.<ref name=retrosheet/>

column6: title=Baseball Myths: Debating, Debunking, and Disproving Tales from the Diamond

column2: leader_title2 = Person in charge of EU relations

column4: title= Transparency Register: European Foundation for Democracy

column1: The '''European Foundation for Democracy''' (EFD) is a policy centre and a [[Lobby register#European Union
column3: EU lobbyist organization]] based in Brussels, Belgium.<ref name=\"EU\"/> Its activities focus on counter-radicalisation, security and the promotion of the [[European values]] of democracy and individual freedoms. Its experts produce analyses and publications concerning the various threats coming from extremist ideologies, recommending measures and policies to counter these phenomena.

column1: EFD also organises public events,<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/> policy briefings<ref>{{Cite web
column2: title = Social media platforms have ‘crucial role to play in combating extremist rhetoric’
column6: title = Leading author calls for ‘attack on all fronts’ against Islamic fundamentalism
column9: access-date = 2016-01-19}}</ref> and roundtable discussions where relevant experts debate specific challenges posed by extremist forces, in order to stimulate the debate and provide the policy community with recommendations on how to tackle such threats.

column1: EFD was founded in November 2005.<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp
column2: 37}} Documents registering EFD at [[Federal Public Service Justice]] date 24 May 2006.<ref name=\"Massoumi, Mills and Miller\"/>{{rp
column3: 193}} Its co-founders were Roberta Bonazzi, Nicola Dell’Arciprete and  Miguel Papi Boucher. Dell’Arciprete previously worked on staff of an Italian [[Member of the European Parliament
column4: MEP]] from far-right [[Lega Nord]], during which he participated in a tour hosted by [[Ateret Cohanim]].<ref name=\"Massoumi, Mills and Miller\"/>{{rp
column5: 191}} On 15 September 2011, the organization was officially registered as an organization that works to influence the lawmaking process of the EU institutions.<ref name=\"EU\"/>

column1: Scholar [[Farid Hafez]] maintains that the EFD hails from a politically [[conservative]] milieu, and its \"fellows are located in the corridors of power\", adding that \"[t]heir experts produce knowledge for highly subsidized state institutions\".<ref name=\"Hafez\"/>{{rp
column2: 130}} Georgetown University's Bridge Initiative profile of EFD, states that the organization has a \"privileged access to financial resources and political decision making\".<ref name=\"Georgetown\"/>

column1: The EFD has campaigned on issues that echo policies advocated by the establishment in [[Israel]], and it has been described as a pro-Israel group.<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp
column2: 38}} The EFD's president denies allegations of being pro-Israel, saying \"We try to not get involved in the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict
column3: Israel-Palestine issue]].... We don't feel able to add anything. We don't think we can do it well.\"<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp

column1: EFD is an advocate of adding [[Hezbollah]] of Lebanon to the [[List of organisations designated as terrorist organisations by the European Union
column2: European Union's list of terrorist organizations]],<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp
column3: 37}} and has proposed a ban on television networks [[Al-Manar]] and [[Al-Aqsa TV]] by the EU.<ref name=\"Massoumi, Mills and Miller\"/>{{rp
column4: 191}} It has hosted events calling for a tougher action against [[Iran]] for its [[Nuclear program of Iran
column5: nuclear programme]].<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp

column1: Multiple scholars have wrote that the EFD is an [[Islamophobic]] organization,<ref name=\"Georgetown\"/> including David Cronin, Sarah Marusek and [[David Miller (political theorist)
column2: David Miller]], who state that the organization is \"closely associated with a transatlantic network of neoconservative and Islamophobic activists\";<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp
column3: 37}} Narzanin Massoumi, Tom Mills and Miller who comment that the organization is \"promoting a range of issues that include Islamophobia\",<ref name=\"Massoumi, Mills and Miller\"/>{{rp
column4: 190}} and [[Farid Hafez]]. Hafez has conducted a [[case study]] on activities of the EFD in [[Austria]]<ref name=\"Hafez\"/>{{rp
column6: 128–130}} in particular works published by the organization to put Austrian Muslim Youth (''Muslimische Jugend Österreich'') and [[Sveriges Unga Muslimer
column7: Young Muslims of Sweden]] (''Sveriges Unga Muslimer'') under government pressure by falsely linking them to [[Muslim Brotherhood]] of Egypt. He concludes that EFD systematically produces works that follows a strategy of [[defamation]] and [[delegitimization]] of actors of the [[civil society]] of Muslims in Europe, by identifying them as [[Radical politics

column1: EFD is described as a \"capital darling\", i.e. a NGO which is is based on [[Financial capital
column5: title=Democracy Building and Civil Society in Post-Soviet Armenia
column9: page=27}}</ref> as well as an organization that enjoys support from several wealthy donors.<ref name=\"Hafez\">{{citation
column16: chapter=Muslim Civil Society Under Attack: The European Foundation for Democracy’s Role in Defaming and Delegitimizing Muslim Civil Society
column17: title=Islamophobia and Radicalization: Breeding Intolerance and Violence

column1: It has received substantial contributions from the [[Federal government of the United States
column2: United States government]], for example out of EFD's declared €520,000 budget between January and September 2012, Some €70,000 was from [[United States Department of State
column3: Department of State]].<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\">{{citation
column10: title=The Israel Lobby and the European Union

column2: title = Money raised by Friends of EFD anually
source = Cronin, Marusek and Miller<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp

column1: In 2009, [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]] (FDD) provided a direct grant of $478,829 to EFD.<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp
In addition, 'Friends  of  the  European  Foundation  for  Democracy' (Friends of EFD), a [[Washington D.C.]]-based tax-exempt organization is dedicated to [[Fundraising
column2: raise funds]] for the EFD, which summed a total of $2,688,500 between 2011 and 2013.<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp

column1: Known co-funders of the Friends of EFD, and the amount of money they donated to the organization from 2009 to 2013 is as follows:
* Bodman Foundation ($50,000)<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp
* Hochberg Family Foundation ($50,000)<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp
* Marcus Foundation ($800,000)<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp

column2: Paul Singer]] ($1,000,000)<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp

column1: The [[Transparency Register]] data of EFD for 2018 fiscal year, declared zero funding received from national sources and local/regional sources, listing all of its budget coming from other sources.<ref name=\"EU\"/>
== Ties to the Foundation for Defense of Democracies ==
EFD maintains organizational as well as financial ties to the U.S.-based [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]] (FDD).<ref name=\"Hafez\"/>{{rp
column2: 120}} The official website of FDD, as of 2007, stated that it works in a \"partnership\" with the EFD.<ref>{{citation
column5: title=A Pact with the Devil: Washington's Bid for World Supremacy and the Betrayal of the American Promise
column9: page=xxviii}}</ref> Scholars Narzanin Massoumi, Tom Mills and [[David Miller (political theorist)
column10: David Miller]] argue that EFD actually \"originates\" from FDD, calling it the latter's \"EU offshoot\" and categorizing it among the \"European-based [[Neoconservatism
column11: neocon]] outfits... set up by US parent organisations\".<ref name=\"Massoumi, Mills and Miller\">{{citation
column18: chapter=Islamophobia, Social Movements and the State: For a Movement-centred Approach
column23: 22}} Bridge Initiative of [[Georgetown University]] identifies FDD and EFD as organizations linked to each other through numerous persons and institutions.<ref name=\"Georgetown\">{{citation
column31: archive-date=13 April 2020}}</ref> The two also share the same major donors.<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp

column1: Roberta Bonazzi, the EFD's director said in 2014 that FDD and EFD are \"two completely separate organisations, financially and legally separate\"; however after being asked about US documents about a financial relationship between the two, replied: \"that is because most of our fundraising is done in the US. [The FDD was] our contact. Grants were sent to them and then to us.\"<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp

* [http://www.fischerverlage.de/buch/generation_allah_warum_wir_im_kampf_gegen_religioesen_extremismus_umdenken_muessen/9783100024466 ''Generation Allah: why we need to rethink our approach to fighting religious extremism'']. Ahmad Mansour. October 2015.
* ''[http://europeandemocracy.eu/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/EFD-Tunisia-FINAL.pdf Tunisia, a nascent democracy under siege]''. Valentina Colombo. September 2015.

* ''[http://europeandemocracy.eu/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/2015-09-Libyas-Fight-for-Survival.pdf Libya’s fight for survival – Defeating Jihadist networks]''. [[Arturo Varvelli]], Stefano Maria Torelli, Valentina Colombo, Giuseppe Dentice, Wolfgang Pusztai, Nancy Porsia. September 2015.
* ''[http://europeandemocracy.eu/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/2015-09-Secularism-in-Azerbaijan.pdf Secularism in Azerbaijan and the threat of radicalisation in the region].'' June 2015.
* ''[http://europeandemocracy.eu/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/A-Nuclear-Deal-with-Iran-Prospects-and-Challenges.pdf A Nuclear Deal with Iran Prospects and Challenges].'' Bruno Tertrais. March 2015

* ''[http://europeandemocracy.eu/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Homegrown-Jihadism-in-Italy.pdf Home-Grown Jihadism in Italy]'' (also available in Italian: ''[http://europeandemocracy.eu/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Il-Jihadismo-Autoctono-in-Italia.pdf Il Jihadismo Autoctono in Italia]''). [[Lorenzo G. Vidino

* ''[http://europeandemocracy.eu/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/radicalisation_in_africa.pdf Radicalisation islamique et enjeux sécuritaires au Sahel. De l'influence wahhabite au terrorisme]''. Bakary Sambe. October 2013.
* ''[http://europeandemocracy.eu/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/Hisba_in_Europe1.pdf Hisba in Europe? Assessing a murky phenomenon].'' [[Lorenzo G. Vidino

column1: It has received substantial contributions from the [[Federal government of the United States

column3: Department of State]].<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\">{{citation

column1: In 2009, [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]] (FDD) provided a direct grant of $478,829 to EFD.<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp
In addition, 'Friends  of  the  European  Foundation  for  Democracy' (Friends of EFD), a [[Washington D.C.]]-based tax-exempt organization is dedicated to [[Fundraising
column2: raise funds]] for the EFD, which summed a total of $2,688,500 between 2011 and 2013.<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp

column1: The [[Transparency Register]] data of EFD for 2018 fiscal year, declared zero funding received from national sources and local/regional sources, listing all of its budget coming from other sources.<ref name=\"EU\"/>
== Ties to the Foundation for Defense of Democracies ==
EFD maintains organizational as well as financial ties to the U.S.-based [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]] (FDD).<ref name=\"Hafez\"/>{{rp
column2: 120}} The official website of FDD, as of 2007, stated that it works in a \"partnership\" with the EFD.<ref>{{citation
column5: title=A Pact with the Devil: Washington's Bid for World Supremacy and the Betrayal of the American Promise
column9: page=xxviii}}</ref> Scholars Narzanin Massoumi, Tom Mills and [[David Miller (political theorist)
column10: David Miller]] argue that EFD actually \"originates\" from FDD, calling it the latter's \"EU offshoot\" and categorizing it among the \"European-based [[Neoconservatism
column11: neocon]] outfits... set up by US parent organisations\".<ref name=\"Massoumi, Mills and Miller\">{{citation
column18: chapter=Islamophobia, Social Movements and the State: For a Movement-centred Approach
column23: 22}} Bridge Initiative of [[Georgetown University]] identifies FDD and EFD as organizations linked to each other through numerous persons and institutions.<ref name=\"Georgetown\">{{citation
column31: archive-date=13 April 2020}}</ref> The two also share the same major donors.<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp

column1: Roberta Bonazzi, the EFD's director said in 2014 that FDD and EFD are \"two completely separate organisations, financially and legally separate\"; however after being asked about US documents about a financial relationship between the two, replied: \"that is because most of our fundraising is done in the US. [The FDD was] our contact. Grants were sent to them and then to us.\"<ref name=\"Cronin, Marusek and Miller\"/>{{rp
